entry.title: why can't 3*3 matrix represent tranlation in 3-D space?
entry.content: why can’t 3*3 matrix represent tranlation in 3-D space?Usually we descibe rotation, scale and translation of a vector by 4*4 matrix, we call it homogeneous space, then project it to 3-D space by being devided by w. In this page we mainly talking about why should we should we do this. Scale Imaging there is a vector$\vec x = \left [\begin{matrix}x_1 \\ x_2\\ x_3 \end{matrix} \right]$,for scaling, we have to multiply each component of the vector by a factor. Proportionally scalingthis means we scale up/down along the direction of the origin vector. In the picture above we can see vector$\vec B =\left [\begin{matrix} 1\\2\\3\end{matrix}\right ],$ and $\vec C =\left [\begin{matrix} 2\\4\\6\end{matrix}\right ]$. Apparently we can find a matrix which makes this equation have a solution: $M·\vec B = \vec C$ M = \left[ \begin{matrix} 2&0&0\\ 0&2&0\\ 0&0&2 \end{matrix} \right]$\begin{matrix}[2&0&0]\end{matrix}$ indicates that we take double $x_1$ from $\vec B$ and none of $x_2$ and $x_3$ to compose $x_1$ of $\vec C$.$\begin{matrix}[0&2&0]\end{matrix}$ indicates that we take double $x_2$ from $\vec B$ and none of $x_1$ and $x_3$ to compose $x_2$ of $\vec C$.$\begin{matrix}[0&0&2]\end{matrix}$ indicates that we take double $x_3$ from $\vec B$ and none of $x_1$ and $x_2$ to compose $x_3$ of $\vec C$.thus we get $\vec C$. Disproportionally scalingthis is a little bit different from proportionally scaling, but we can still use a 3*3 matrix to describe this operation.similar to proportionally scaling, when we have $\vec M·\vec B = \vec C$, we got$M =\left[\begin{matrix}1&0&0\\0&2&0\\0&0&1\end{matrix}\right]$. RotationRotate around the axisFor example , we rotate the vector $\vec {OP}$ around the Z axis. In the original coordinate $\dot P$ lies at$\left[\begin{matrix}x_a,y_a\end{matrix}\right ]$(we don’t care about Z because Z keeps as it is).we give it a clockwise rotation around Z axis, the it lies at $\left[\begin{matrix}x_b,y_b\end{matrix}\right ]$, pay attention to the picture above , here we rotate $\vec {OP}$ clockwise , in other words , we can keep $\dot P$ where it is and rotate the axis anti-clockwise which is shown in the picture. According to the triangle congruence theorems , we got equations below: \left\{ \begin{aligned} x_b &=& x_a\cdot \cos\theta + y_a \cdot \sin\theta ,\\ y_b &=& -x_a\cdot \sin\theta + y_a \cdot \cos\theta \end{aligned} \right.we write them in matrix format : \left [ \begin{matrix} x_b\\y_b \end{matrix} \right] = \left [ \begin{matrix} \cos\theta & \sin\theta \\ -\sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{matrix} \right] \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} x_a\\y_a \end{matrix} \right]and we add Z in : \left [ \begin{matrix} x_b\\y_b\\z_b \end{matrix} \right] = \left [ \begin{matrix} \cos\theta & \sin\theta & 0\\ -\sin\theta & \cos\theta & 0\\ 0& 0&1 \end{matrix} \right] \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} x_a\\y_a\\z_a \end{matrix} \right]similarlly rotate around X axis : \left [ \begin{matrix} x_b\\y_b\\z_b \end{matrix} \right] = \left [ \begin{matrix} 1& 0&0\\ 0&\cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ 0&\sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{matrix} \right] \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} x_a\\y_a\\z_a \end{matrix} \right]and around Y axis : \left [ \begin{matrix} x_b\\y_b\\z_b \end{matrix} \right] = \left [ \begin{matrix} \cos\theta &0& \sin\theta \\ 0& 1&0\\ -\sin\theta &0& \cos\theta \end{matrix} \right] \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} x_a\\y_a\\z_a \end{matrix} \right]if we rotate aound a random vector $\vec v =\left[\begin{matrix}u\\v\\w\end{matrix}\right]$ , it’s little bit complicated but we can break it down into a set of rotation around axis , you can have a try if you are interested in it. Finally we got this : \left [ \begin{matrix} x_b\\y_b\\z_b \end{matrix} \right] = M \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} x_a\\y_a\\z_a \end{matrix} \right] M = \left [ \begin{matrix} u^2 + (1-u^2)\cdot\cos\theta& u\cdot v\cdot(1-\cos\theta) - w\cdot\sin\theta&u\cdot w\cdot(1-\cos\theta) + v\cdot\sin\theta\\ u\cdot v\cdot(1-\cos\theta) + w\cdot\sin\theta&v^2+(1-v^2)\cdot\cos\theta&v\cdot w\cdot(1-\cos\theta)-u\cdot \sin\theta\\ u\cdot w\cdot(1-\cos\theta) + v\cdot\sin\theta& v\cdot w\cdot(1-\cos\theta)+u\cdot \sin\theta& w^2 + (1-w^2)\cdot\cos\theta \end{matrix} \right]see we can handle rotation by 3*3 matrix. TranslationNo mater where we tranlate the vector, it still lies in the 3-D space. Now there is a vector $\vec v_1 = \left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\y_1\\z_1\end{matrix}\right]$ , after tranlation it is $\vec v_2 = \left[\begin{matrix}x_2\\y_2\\z_2\end{matrix}\right]$, if the tranlation factor is d, then the equation below is established: \left[\begin{matrix}x_2\\y_2\\z_2\end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix}x_1+d\\y_1+d\\z_1+d\end{matrix}\right]we simply split the d out : \left[\begin{matrix}x_2\\y_2\\z_2\end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix}x_1\\y_1\\z_1\end{matrix}\right] + \left[\begin{matrix}d\\d\\d\end{matrix}\right]\downarrow \vec v_2 = \vec v_1 + d \tag{3.1}If we gonna prove translation can be implemented by 3*3 matrix, we are going to prove $(3.2)$ in other words. Here comes the point, we can’t find a matrix that satisfies a equation of the following form. M\cdot\vec v_1 = \vec v_1 + d \tag {3.2}now we are going to prove our conclusion in linear algebra. If we combine with scale and rotation which will be more generetic : M \cdot\vec v_1 = A\cdot\vec v_1 + d \tag {3.3}when M = $E$ and A = $E$ $(E=\left[\begin{matrix}1&0&0\\0&1&0\\0&0&1\end{matrix}\right])$ it becomes the equation above$(3.1)$. and we write it in matrix form: \left [ \begin{matrix} M&0 \end{matrix} \right]_{3\times4} \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} v_1\\1 \end{matrix} \right]_{4\times1} = \left [ \begin{matrix} A&d \end{matrix} \right]_{3\times4} \cdot \left [ \begin{matrix} v_1\\1 \end{matrix} \right]_{4\times1} \tag{3.4}Consider the column rank of matrix :$Rank(M) = 3$ , $Rank(A) = 3$ ,$Rank(\left [\begin{matrix}M&0\end{matrix}\right]) = 3$$Rank(\left [\begin{matrix}A&1\end{matrix}\right]) = 4$. see $(3.4)$ can be satisfied only when $d = \left [\begin{matrix}0\\0\\0\end{matrix}\right]$ and $M = A$, otherwise it’s not equal. When $d = \left [\begin{matrix}0\\0\\0\end{matrix}\right]$ it’s a translation that goes through the origin(relatively), no translation in other words : )
